title: Authors and Citation
text: Alicia Foxx. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Foxx (2024). foxxlab: Data Package Datasets Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab. R package version 0.2.0, https://aliciafoxx.github.io/foxxlab/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {foxxlab: Data Package With Datasets From The Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab},   author = {Alicia Foxx},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://aliciafoxx.github.io/foxxlab/}, }

title: Data Package With Datasets From The Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab
text: foxxlab R package providing library datasets Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab, ranging plant ecology social science topics. Currently, foxxlab offers variety datastes including meta-analysis datasets promote open science serve training materials visualizations analyses including meta-analyses.

title: Data Package With Datasets From The Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab
text: Install latest development version GitHub (requires devtools package):
code: if (!require("devtools")) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::install_github("aliciafoxx/foxxlab", dependencies = TRUE, build_vignettes = T)

title: Data Package With Datasets From The Foxx Disrupting Ecology Lab
text: visualization example fk2020b dataset foxxlab:
code: library(foxxlab) library(ggrain) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)   foxxlab::fk2020b |>   dplyr::rename(`height (mm)` = Height_.mm.) |>   ggplot(aes(1, `height (mm)`,              fill = Collection_type)) +   ggrain::geom_rain(alpha = .5) +   theme_classic() +   xlab("variation") +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = 'Dark2')

title: Dataset Description — f2021
text: dataset contains information Pascopyrum smithii dataset.

title: Dataset Description — f2021
text: data frame 87 rows 17 variables: Numeric vector representing observation number. Focal_Species Character vector representing focal species. Non-focal_plant Character vector representing non-focal plant species. Treatment Character vector representing treatment applied. Exp Character vector representing experimental condition. No_of_Root_Tips Numeric vector representing number root tips. Total_Mass_Exp_1 Numeric vector representing total mass Experiment 1. Root_Mass_Exp_1 Numeric vector representing root mass Experiment 1. Shoot_Mass_Exp_1 Numeric vector representing shoot mass Experiment 1. Plant_Height(mm)_Exp_1 Numeric vector representing plant height millimeters Experiment 1. RMF_Exp_1 Numeric vector representing root mass fraction Experiment 1. Community_Rhizome_Exp_2 Numeric vector representing community rhizome Experiment 2. Notes Logical vector indicating presence notes. All_Focal_Shoot_Mass Numeric vector representing shoot mass focal plants. focal_leaf_count Numeric vector representing leaf count focal plants. nf_leaf_count_1 Numeric vector representing leaf count non-focal plants (1st count). nf_leaf_count_2 Numeric vector representing leaf count non-focal plants (2nd count).

title: Dataset Description — f2021
text: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-021-93494-0

title: Dataset Description — f2021
text: Abstract: Plants can interact different individuals lifetime may lead plastic response affect performance. conspecific interactions altered previous plastic responses affect stabilizing niche mechanisms, conspecifics compete intensely promote diversity coexistence. , show interactions Pascopyrum smithii conspecifics resulted largely canalized traits, whereas P. smithii invasive grass, Bromus tectorum resulted plastic responses root mass (p = 0.02), shoot mass (p < 0.0001), root mass fraction (p = 0.003) plant height (p < 0.0001). subset individuals transplanted two interaction treatments moved new, aged conspecifics showed previous interactions led differing trait relationships: increases number leaves interspecific-induced plants related increases non-focal leaf production, whereas increases number leaves intraspecific-induced plants related decreases non-focal plants (R2 = 0.52, p = 0.006). results suggest previous intraspecific interactions intensify conspecific competition stabilize subsequent interactions conspecifics imposing greater competition, invasive-interspecific interactions can weaken stabilizing niche mechanisms, thus negatively influencing species coexistence.

title: Dataset Description — f2024
text: Abstract: Invasive plant species devastate native plant communities, often strong influences belowground mechanisms. However, native plants responded rapid trait change due multigenerational interactions invasives, including root biomass allocation. Native plant root allocation responses context poorly typified although invasive species likely pronounced influences belowground native plants. Additionally, whether resource availability mediates responses invader-naïve invader-experienced plants yet summarized. address gaps, meta-analyzed studies evaluated root partitioning (root mass fraction; RMF) invader-experienced invader-naïve native populations, experiments native plants grown alone co-occurring invasive species varying resource levels. Using 242 effect sizes 17 native species, found differences response presence absence multigenerational invasive exposure apparent resource levels applied. Specifically, grown alone, invader-experienced plants greater RMF resource stress lower RMF high resource availability, invader-naïve plants demonstrated opposite pattern (p < 0.001). results demonstrate invasive plant exposure produced adaptive responses resources observed even without interactions invasives. results indicate greater influence invasive species belowground call research assessing ecological evolutionary root trait responses coexistence invasive species.

title: Dataset Description — ff2019

title: Dataset Description — ff2019
text: data frame 92 observations 21 variables: . Numeric. Observation number. Study Character. Name study. Study_location Character. Location study. Target_species Character. Species targeted study. Target_life_history Character. Life history target species. Target_functional_group Character. Functional group target species. Study_type Character. Type study (e.g., Outdoor, Indoor). study_unit Character. Unit study (e.g., mesocosm, plot). Water_trt Character. Water treatment applied. Comp_trt Character. Component treatment applied (e.g., Shoot_Comp, Root_Comp). Response_unit Character. Unit response variable measured. mean Numeric. Mean value response variable. se Numeric. Standard error mean. std Numeric. Standard deviation. N Numeric. Number observations. Cntrl_Mean Numeric. Mean value control group. Cntrl_STD Numeric. Standard deviation control group. Cntrl_N Numeric. Number observations control group. notes Character. Additional notes comments. LRR Numeric. Log response ratio. LRR_var Numeric. Variance log response ratio.

title: Dataset Description — ff2019
text: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0220674

title: Dataset Description — ff2019
text: Abstract: Background: Competition critical process shapes plant communities interacts environmental constraints. surprising knowledge gaps related mechanisms belie competitive processes, though important natural communities agricultural systems: contribution different plant parts competitive outcomes effect environmental constraints outcomes.Objective: Studies partition competition root-shoot-interactions assess whether plant parts impose different competitive intensities using physical partitions serve important way fill knowledge gaps. Given predicted drought escalation due climate change, focused systematic review–including meta-analysis effects water supply competitive outcomes. Methods: searched ISI Web Science peer-reviewed studies found 2042 results. eleven suitable studies, five extractable information 80 effect sizes 10 species test effects. used meta-analysis compare log response ratios (lnRR) biomass responses competition roots, shoots, full plants two water levels. Results: Water availability treatment competition treatment (root-, shoot-, full plant competition) significantly interacted affect plant growth responses (p < 0.0001). Root-full plant competition intense low water availability (-1.2 -0.9 mean lnRR, respectively) conditions shoot-competition (-0.2 mean lnRR). However, shoot-competition high water availability intense (— 0.78 mean lnRR) compared root-full competition (-0.5 0.61 mean lnRR, respectively) showing opposite pattern low water availability. results also show intensity full competition similar root-competition low water availability intensifies root competition weakening shoot competition. Conclusions: outcome competition intense roots low water availability emphasizes importance root competition patterns competition may shift changing climate, creating urgency studies fil knowledge gaps addressing issues drought plant interactions communities.

title: Dataset Description — ffk2024
text: Abstract: Evaluating restoration practices admixture provenancing, mixing multiple source populations greater intraspecific variation plant restorations, helps understand utility practice different scenarios. admixture provenancing, know whether just population mixture deliver positive outcomes mixed scenarios. understand populations species identity influence plant performance trait outcomes mixtures, assessed trait variation among populations two forb species native western US (Dieteria canescens Heterotheca villosa) following three interaction treatments (single-population monoculture, two-population mixture, two-species mixture) Dieteria canescens focal plant greenhouse common environment. Plants harvested seven weeks growth plant height, leaf count, root length, root mass fraction traits measured, well whole plant biomass. found four six population pairings led positive interactions compared single population monocultures. Neighbor trait differences shoot height root length best predicted plant growth following interactions, increasing neighbor trait differences resulted positive growth outcomes one trait treatment interaction. single case, plant growth decreased increasing differences root mass fraction two-species mixture treatment, surprisingly. findings show nuance outcomes interactions within populations species: highly dependent population identity traits measured, aspects must considered evaluating restoration materials.

title: Dataset Description — fk2020b
text: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/rec.13336

title: Dataset Description — fk2020b
text: Abstract: Restoration practitioners many seed material choices restoring plant communities, cultivars may affordable accessible material available species. However, process plant selection commercial seed production can limit trait variability critical survival persistence heterogeneous environments. Several studies show impacts plant selection commercial production trait values variation aboveground traits. Yet, researchers rarely assess impacts root traits wild-collected material relative cultivars. critical gap, especially arid environments root traits play key roles plant survival. grew Pseudoroegneria spicata seedlings three wild accessions three cultivars (cultivars “Whitmar” “Goldar,” “selected germplasm polycross” “P-7”) compare root shoot traits variability. grew seedlings growth chamber 4 weeks sand, low moisture content added nutrients, resulting stressful conditions. harvested plants compared trait variation averages wild-collected versus cultivars four shoot four root traits. found wild accessions marginally greater variation root tip count, root mass fraction, shoot mass fraction. Importantly, wild-collected plants 51% root tips average, greater variability four seven traits exhibited differing variability collection types, greater survival compared cultivars. results indicate differences traits variation wild cultivated accessions considered choosing material restoration use.

text: Abstract: Exposure competition invasive plants multiple generations, multigenerational invasive exposure can drive rapid native plant trait change. invasive plant effects can concentrated belowground, studies consider native plant root trait responses multigenerational invasive exposure.  quantified root shoot trait responses native grass Sporobolus airoides response multigenerational invasive exposure. S. airoides sourced invader-experienced subpopulations co-occurred field 58 years average invasive Russian knapweed (Rhaponticum repens) nearby invader-naïve plants co-occur invasive. Maternal plants subpopulations collected , transplanted greenhouse Wyoming, USA. first generation seeds transplants collected grown another round seed collection (generation two). grew invader-experienced invader-naïve seedlings generations growth chamber Illinois, USA. found largest shifts root traits invasive exposure status (e.g., root mass fraction (standardized mean difference (SMD) = 0.5), primary root count (SMD) = 0.52), root length (SMD) = 0.44)); invader-experienced plants significantly larger root traits generation two, associated greater survival, thus may adaptive.
